â€˜The Extreme Always Seems To Make An Impressionâ€™: Reviewing Heathers the Musical

12/05/2023

Emily Warner (she/her) reviews Heathers the Musical.

Image by Pamela Raith

By Emily Warner

Content Warning: This article contains references to suicide, eating disorders and sexual abuse.

This cult classic has undergone many evolutions since it was first written in 1989, but its popularity and fun have not diminished with time. Very much a product of the â€˜80s, the musical deals with themes that seem unlikely to work on stage; teen suicide, bulimia, date rape and highschoolers pulling guns on their classmates (itâ€™s not exactly â€˜Les Misâ€™, is it?). However, the surreal, slightly sardonic tone helps to lighten the weight of these topics. Heathers the musical does a lot to temper the darkness and moral ambiguities of the original film, boldly owning the title â€˜black comedyâ€™. It finds fun in its savagery and on its opening night in York, every audience member found themselves laughing (yes, laughing) along.

Explaining the plot of Heathers is like describing a crazy dream to a friend; â€œeveryone died and resurrected and went to prom and there were some slushies and croquet. The love interest was a handsome, mysterious school shooter and the antagonist was a bully who drank a mug of bleach. Oh yeah, and there was a gay plotline during a funeral, partway through the second half. Man did I envy those rainbow ties.â€

Imagine the look on your friend's face. Theyâ€™d probably be calling a therapist three seconds into the story.

Toeing the line between comedy, campness and genuine pathos, the musical is delightfully scattered with quotable one-liners as well as breathtaking moments of vulnerability. Heather Mcnamaraâ€™sÂ  performance of â€˜Lifeboatâ€™ for example, reveals very real insecurities (performed by Billie Bowman) and Martha Dunstockâ€™s â€˜Kindergarten Boyfriendâ€™ offers a rare moment when we see her as a human being, rather than a laughing stock (performed by Kingsley Morton). Even J. D. (performed by Jacob Fowler) has his moment of sympathy when we learnt about his past, that is, before he plants a bomb in the school and forges a mass suicide pact.

However, testament to the phenomenal cast, there were moments of great comedy too. The cartoonish stupidity of Ram Sweeney (Morgan Jackson) and Kurt Kelly (Alex Woodward), hyperbolised their â€˜high school bullyâ€™ role to the point of absurdity. Much of the time, the pair dressed and acted the same, presenting as a kind of comedy double-act. Even at the darkest point in their story, moments before they were murdered, they pranced around the stage in matching boxers and performed a hilarious crotch-bump (a word I just invented to describe a chest bump with the pelvic area). Furthermore, their dads continued the farce in the second half (Jay Bryce and Conor McFarlane). During the boys funeral, they declare love for one another and perform the song â€˜I Love my Dead Gay Sonâ€™ with a church congregation of back-up dancers â€“ I never realised how entertaining it would be to witness the queering of a funeral.

The three Heathers were equally memorable. Each one possessed their own spotlight, corresponding to the colour they were dressed in, so their scenes were an interplay of contrasting colours and polished dance moves. Their verbal sparring and power dynamics were all executed to perfection â€“ the Heathers make sure to look good even while theyâ€™re fighting. However, their cruelty and ruthlessness was tinged with an element of ridicule. Everything they did was topped with theatrical flair so the rule of the â€˜lipstick Gestapoâ€™ was self-consciously caricatured. And for good reason; Iâ€™m not sure their world of bullying, alcoholism, drugs, and suicide would be funny, if it wasnâ€™t ludicrous (why do you think the musical has aged better than the film?).

The songs were vibrant, sequin-fuelled displays. Their tendency to get stuck in your head was undeniable and the energy of the performers in every number was faultless. It could be argued that there was an uncomfortable disjunct between the pizazz of these songs and the hefty subject matter of the musical. Many scenes seemed to follow a skewed sequence; a dead teenager, a memorial service, cue the jazz hands. However, this divide must be viewed with an acceptance of what it conceals. The humour does not seek to diminish these issues but opens up much needed conversations about mental health and sexual abuse. Therefore, despite the comedic handling of these themes the musical does gesture towards a deeper awareness of them.

The story culminates at senior prom. While the cheerleaders wave their pom poms in the auditorium, J. D. 's unhinged plot to blow up the school unfolds below. The juxtaposition of lights, music and dance with the smoky underbelly of the school, perfectly encapsulated what the musical tries to achieve as a whole. A symbolic representation of the darker subplots behind this kitschy, jukebox spectacle.

Heathers is a riotously entertaining Musical, with a surreal slide into something darker and more unhinged than its bright colours would suggest. So, despite its more problematic aspects, â€œf*ck me gently with a chainsawâ€ was this a good musical (to echo the sentiment of Heather Chandler). If you want escapism, fun and laughter then look no further than this dark comedy. However, be prepared to leave the theatre feeling like you enjoyed something twisted and wildly inappropriate for humour. Perhaps that is the point; to provoke, to enthral, to ask of its audience, â€˜Have you got a problem?â€™

Itâ€™s no fault of the musical that we do.

Editorâ€™s Note: Heathers the Musical is on at Grand Opera House, York from 9 May - 13 May.
